title: 106_s1917
content: The Federal Death Penalty Abolition Act of 1999 is referred to as the "Federal Death Penalty Abolition Act of 1999". It repeals federal laws that provide for the death penalty. The Federal Death Penalty Abolition Act of 1999 repeals federal laws allowing the death penalty for specific homicide-related offenses. The Federal Death Penalty Abolition Act of 1999 eliminates the death penalty for civil rights offenses resulting in death, murder of certain officials, and death resulting from offenses involving transportation. The Federal Death Penalty Abolition Act of 1999 removes the death penalty for offenses involving transportation of explosives, destruction of government property, or murder committed by use of a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. The Federal Death Penalty Abolition Act of 1999 removes the death penalty for various offenses under title 18, United States Code, by striking "by death or" in multiple sections related to genocide, first degree murder, murder by a federal prisoner, and murder of a state or local law enforcement official. The Federal Death Penalty Abolition Act of 1999 removes the death penalty for specific offenses under title 18, United States Code, by striking "by death or" in various sections related to murder of law enforcement officials, kidnapping, hostage-taking, and preventing testimony by a witness. The Federal Death Penalty Abolition Act of 1999 removes the death penalty for specific offenses under title 18, United States Code, by striking "by death or" in various sections related to murder, assassination, kidnapping, and racketeering. The Federal Death Penalty Abolition Act of 1999 removes the death penalty for specific offenses under title 18, United States Code, by striking certain phrases in various sections related to murder, train wrecking, bank robbery, carjacking, aggravated child sexual abuse, and sexual abuse. The Federal Death Penalty Abolition Act of 1999 removes the death penalty for specific offenses under title 18, United States Code, by striking certain phrases in various sections related to murder, train wrecking, bank robbery, carjacking, aggravated child sexual abuse, and sexual abuse. This includes murder related to sexual exploitation of children, murder committed during an offense against maritime navigation, murder committed during an offense against a maritime fixed platform, terrorist murder of a United States national in another country, and murder by the use of a weapon of mass destruction. The Federal Death Penalty Abolition Act of 1999 removes the death penalty for specific offenses under title 18, United States Code, by striking certain phrases in various sections related to murder, train wrecking, bank robbery, carjacking, aggravated child sexual abuse, and sexual abuse. This includes murder involving torture, murder related to a continuing criminal enterprise or related murder of a federal, state, or local law enforcement officer. The Federal Death Penalty Abolition Act of 1999 removes the death penalty for specific offenses under title 18, United States Code, by amending certain subsections and striking phrases related to sentencing. The Federal Death Penalty Abolition Act of 1999 removes the death penalty for specific offenses under title 18, United States Code, by amending certain subsections and striking phrases related to sentencing. This includes amendments to sections regarding aircraft hijacking, espionage, and treason, as well as the repeal of criminal procedures relating to the imposition of the death sentence. The Federal Death Penalty Abolition Act of 1999 removes the death penalty for specific offenses under title 18, United States Code, by repealing Chapter 228 and making technical amendments to the table of chapters. The Federal Death Penalty Abolition Act of 1999 prohibits the imposition of death sentences for violations of Federal law. Any person previously sentenced to death will now serve a life sentence without parole.
